Cyclophilins are enzymes catalyzing thecis-trans isomerization of peptidyl-prolyl bonds and belong to the enzyme class of peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerases (PPIases), which includes two more families (FK506 binding proteins and parvulins). We report the characterization of a novel cyclophilin (Moca-cyp) isolated from Drosophila melanogaster. The single-copy Moca-cyp gene, which is localized on chromosome 3R, was cloned and sequenced. The sequence alignment of the gene against Moca-cyp cDNA allowed us to define its intron/exon structure and to identify a variant cDNA corresponding to an alternatively spliced mRNA. By embryo in situ RNA hybridization and immunostaining, we show that the expression ofMoca-cyp is regulated during embryogenesis ofDrosophila. The 120-kDa nuclear Moca-cyp protein belongs to a subfamily of large cyclophilins sharing structural and enzymatic features: their highly conserved N-terminal PPIase domain is extended by a positively charged and divergent C-terminal tail. Compared with cyclophilin 18, the enzymatic activity carried by the PPIase domain of Moca-cyp is low, exhibits characteristic substrate specificity, and shows a reduced sensitivity to the drug cyclosporin A (CsA). The reduced affinity for CsA is one of the typical features linking members of this subfamily and is probably the consequence of two amino acid substitutions within their active site. Another structural feature shared by members of this subfamily is a conserved polypeptidic segment (“moca” domain) that we report for the first time. The moca domain is located within the C-terminal tail and is the exclusive hallmark of a group of large cyclophilins found in multicellular organisms of the animal kingdom. Cyclophilins are enzymes catalyzing thecis-trans isomerization of peptidyl-prolyl bonds and belong to the enzyme class of peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerases (PPIases), which includes two more families (FK506 binding proteins and parvulins). We report the characterization of a novel cyclophilin (Moca-cyp) isolated from Drosophila melanogaster. The single-copy Moca-cyp gene, which is localized on chromosome 3R, was cloned and sequenced. The sequence alignment of the gene against Moca-cyp cDNA allowed us to define its intron/exon structure and to identify a variant cDNA corresponding to an alternatively spliced mRNA. By embryo in situ RNA hybridization and immunostaining, we show that the expression ofMoca-cyp is regulated during embryogenesis ofDrosophila. The 120-kDa nuclear Moca-cyp protein belongs to a subfamily of large cyclophilins sharing structural and enzymatic features: their highly conserved N-terminal PPIase domain is extended by a positively charged and divergent C-terminal tail. Compared with cyclophilin 18, the enzymatic activity carried by the PPIase domain of Moca-cyp is low, exhibits characteristic substrate specificity, and shows a reduced sensitivity to the drug cyclosporin A (CsA). The reduced affinity for CsA is one of the typical features linking members of this subfamily and is probably the consequence of two amino acid substitutions within their active site. Another structural feature shared by members of this subfamily is a conserved polypeptidic segment (“moca” domain) that we report for the first time. The moca domain is located within the C-terminal tail and is the exclusive hallmark of a group of large cyclophilins found in multicellular organisms of the animal kingdom. Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerases (PPIase 1The abbreviations used are: PPIase, peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase; cyp18, cyclophilin 18; CsA, cyclosporin A; GST, glutathione S-transferase; NLS, nuclear localization signal; BP-NLS, bipartite NLS; pol II, polymerase II; TPR, tetratricopeptide; RT, reverse transcription; Tricine, N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine; RACE, rapid amplification of cDNA ends; HMM, Hidden Markov Model; HCA, Hydrophobic Cluster Analysis; MBF1, multiprotein bridging factor 1; S6K, S6 kinase; pNA, p-nitroanilide; ORF, open reading frame; CTD, C-terminal domain; FKBP, FK506 binding protein. ; EC 5.2.1.8) are enzymes catalyzing the cis-trans isomerization of peptidyl-prolyl bonds and gather three families of proteins: cyclophilins, FKBP (FK506 binding proteins), and parvulins (for reviews see Refs. 1Fischer G. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. 1994; 33: 1415-1436Google Scholar and 2Ivery M.T.G. Med. Res. Rev. 2000; 20: 452-484Google Scholar). The prototypic cyclophilin (cyp18) was isolated as the cellular receptor for the immunosuppressant drug cyclosporin A (CsA) (3Handschumacher R.E. Harding M.W. Rice J. Drugge R.J. Science. 1984; 226: 544-547Google Scholar) and shown to be a PPIase (4Fischer G. Wittmann-Liebold B. Lang K. Kiefhaber T. Schmid F.X. Nature. 1989; 337: 476-478Google Scholar, 5Takahashi N. Hayano T. Suzuki M. Nature. 1989; 337: 473-475Google Scholar). In T cells, CsA exerts its immunosuppressive effect by inhibiting the calcium-dependent phases of interleukin-2 production (6Schreiber S. Science. 1991; 251: 283-287Google Scholar). The molecular mechanism underlying this immunosuppressive effect involves the binding of the CsA·cyp18 complex to the phosphatase calcineurin (7Friedman J. Weissman I. Cell. 1991; 66: 799-806Google Scholar, 8Liu J. Farmer J.D. Lane W.S. Friedman J. Weissman I. Schreiber S.L. Cell. 1991; 66: 807-815Google Scholar), which in turn leads to the inhibition of the translocation of the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) transcription factor to the nucleus and prevention of interleukin-2 gene transcription (9Jain J. Loh C. Rao A. Curr. Opin. Immunol. 1995; 7: 333-342Google Scholar). Studies have shown that inhibition of the PPIase activity of cyp18 does not mediate immunosuppressive effects (10Snyder S.H. Lai M.M. Burnett P.E. Neuron. 1998; 21: 283-294Google Scholar). Since this first discovery, many other family members have been isolated from different tissues and organisms. From bacteria to humans, they are ubiquitously, abundantly expressed and show a very strong conservation of their PPIase domain (1Fischer G. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. 1994; 33: 1415-1436Google Scholar, 11Galat A. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1999; 371: 149-162Google Scholar). Cyclophilins have been localized in different cell compartments, and their poorly understood functions have been so far linked to multiple cellular processes, such as protein folding (12Schiene C. Fischer G. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2000; 10: 40-45Google Scholar), trafficking (13Colley N.J. Baker E.K. Stamnes M.A. Zuker C.S. Cell. 1991; 67: 255-263Google Scholar), chaperone activity (14Ferreira P.A. Nakayama T.A. Pak W.L. Travis G.H. Nature. 1996; 383: 637-640Google Scholar), oxidative stress response (15Santos A.N. Korber S. Kullertz G. Fischer G. Fischer B. Biol. Reprod. 2000; 62: 1-7Google Scholar), and functional arrangement of components within receptor complexes (16Schiene-Fischer C. Yu C. FEBS Lett. 2001; 495: 1-6Google Scholar). The abundance and ubiquitous expression of these proteins have suggested that their function might be pleiotropic, but a growing body of evidence points toward the fact that different cyclophilins function in a restricted and specific manner. For instance, their specific localization in different cellular compartments might be an indication of their specificity of substrate and function. The specific function of a given cyclophilin will depend not only on its PPIase domain structure but also on the composition of the surrounding segments, which will dictate its cellular localization and interaction with partners. Structural and experimental studies of these polypeptidic domains will be of great interest in the understanding of the functional regulation of cyclophilins. This may make it possible to link a particular cyclophilin to a given signal transduction pathway. For example, cyp18, which does not span behind the PPIase domain, is predominantly cytoplasmic (11Galat A. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1999; 371: 149-162Google Scholar). Some others, like human cyp23 and cyp22 possess, respectively, secretory and mitochondrial targeting signal peptides (1Fischer G. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. Engl. 1994; 33: 1415-1436Google Scholar). Another cyclophilin, Drosophila ninaA, a membrane protein localized in the secretory pathway, is responsible of the correct folding of rhodopsins in the compound eye (13Colley N.J. Baker E.K. Stamnes M.A. Zuker C.S. Cell. 1991; 67: 255-263Google Scholar). The structure of ninaA is in coherence with its localization, because to its PPIase domain is attached an N-terminal signal peptide and a very hydrophobic C-terminal tail. Another subfamily of cyclophilins gather cyp40-like proteins (17Kieffer L.J. Thalhammer T. Handschumacher R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 5503-5507Google Scholar), which are conserved from yeast to humans. Their PPIase domain is extended by a protein-protein interaction domain containing tetratricopeptide (TPR) repeats and a calmodulin binding sequence. Through its TPR domain, Cyp40 associates with the inactive unliganded steroid receptor·Hsp90 chaperone complex (18Pratt W.B. Toft D.O. Endocr. Rev. 1997; 18: 306-360Google Scholar). What about the nucleus? Nup358 cyclophilin belongs to the nuclear pore complex and seems to take part in the trafficking of macromolecules (19Wu J. Matunis M. Kraemer D. Blobel G. Coutavas E. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 14209-14213Google Scholar). This very large nucleoporin, including Ran-binding domains, bears the PPIase domain at its C terminus. Other nuclear cyclophilins have been suspected to play a role in RNA metabolism. For instance, cyp33, isolated from human T cells, which contains an RNA-binding domain in addition to its PPIase active site, has been shown to bind poly(A) or poly(U) polyribonucleotides (20Mi H. Kops O. Zimmermann E. Jaschke A. Tropschug M. FEBS Lett. 1996; 398: 201-205Google Scholar). The human srcyp (21Nestel F.P. Colwill K. Harper S. Pawson T. Anderson S.K. Gene. 1996; 180: 151-155Google Scholar, 22Bourquin J.-P. Stagljar I. Meier P. Moosmann P. Silke J. Baechi T. Georgiev O. Schaffner W. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2055-2061Google Scholar) and its rat homolog matrincyp (23Mortillaro M.J. Berezney R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 8183-8192Google Scholar) are other examples of cyclophilins suspected to play a role in RNA processing. In keeping with their nuclear localization, these cyclophilins bear multiple NLS within their long positively charged C-terminal tails. We report the cloning and characterization of Moca-cyp, a newDrosophila melanogaster nuclear cyclophilin. This protein belongs to a subfamily of large cyclophilins, found in multicellular eukaryotic organisms of the animal kingdom. Specific structural and enzymatic features defining this subfamily are described within this report. The expression of Moca-cyp is regulated duringDrosophila embryogenesis. We also show the existence of a variant Moca-cyp cDNA corresponding to an alternatively spliced mRNA. Finally, we discuss the potential implication of this family of cyclophilins in the regulation of transcription and/or splicing. The recombinant plasmid pGEX-dCBP/CH3 was constructed, using the following procedures: poly(A)+ mRNAs purified (Quick Prep micro purification kit, AmershamBiosciences) from Drosophila Schneider (S2) cells (24Schneider I. J. Embryol. Exp. Morphol. 1972; 27: 353-365Google Scholar) were reverse transcribed (RT) using the murine Moloney leukemia virus reverse transcriptase (Stratagene) and random primer d(N)6 (New England BioLabs). RT products were PCR-amplified using a set ofDrosophila CBP (dCBP) (25Akimaru H. Chen Y. Dai P. Hou D.-X. Nonaka M. Smolik s.M. Armstrong S. Goodman R.H. Ishii S. Nature. 1997; 386: 735-738Google Scholar) gene-specific primers, 5′-TGAAGTCAGCGGCGATGGC-3′ and 5′-GGGGATCACCTGTTGGCT-3′ extended, respectively, with EcoR1 and BglII cloning sites. The 998-bp-amplified dCBP fragment (nucleotides 6892–7890 of published cDNA sequence (25Akimaru H. Chen Y. Dai P. Hou D.-X. Nonaka M. Smolik s.M. Armstrong S. Goodman R.H. Ishii S. Nature. 1997; 386: 735-738Google Scholar)) was digested with EcoR1 andBglII restriction enzymes (New England BioLabs) and ligated to the same cloning sites of pBluescriptSK(−) (Stratagene). The recombinant plasmid pBlue31.9, thus obtained, was used for the construction of GST fusion expression plasmid. Briefly, after digestion with Msc1 (in the cDNA) and NotI (in the vector) enzymes, the dCBP fragment (nucleotides 7365–7890 of published cDNA sequence (25Akimaru H. Chen Y. Dai P. Hou D.-X. Nonaka M. Smolik s.M. Armstrong S. Goodman R.H. Ishii S. Nature. 1997; 386: 735-738Google Scholar)) was released, from pBlue31.9 plasmid, Klenow-treated and cloned into SmaI cloning site of pGEX2TK vector (Amersham Biosciences). The recombinant plasmid pGEX-dCBP/CH3, thus obtained, was used for fusion protein production and radiolabeling as described previously (26Kaelin W.G. Pallas D.C. DeCaprio J.A. Kaye F.J. Livingston D.M. Cell. 1991; 64: 521-532Google Scholar). Plasmids pBluescript814 and pBluescript532 (respectively, nucleotides 2046–3177 and nucleotides 40–3177 of Moca-cypcDNA) are in vivo excision products of recombinant phages lambdaZAP-814 and lambdaZAP-532 (according to the Stratagenein vivo excision procedure) isolated by cDNA library screening (see below). By inserting the XbaI-BamH1 polylinker fragment of pET-19 vector (Novagen) into the same cloning sites of pBluescript814, a translation initiation codon (ATG) was added to the 5′-end of the partial Moca-cyp cDNA 814. The new recombinant plasmid pMet814 was used for in vitrotranscription and translation experiments. p814ES is a recombinant pBluescript plasmid containing an EcoR1-SpeI fragment of Moca-cyp cDNA (nucleotides 2046–2552). The pSKPCR2–532 plasmid was constructed for whole-mount RNA in situ hybridization probe preparation. Briefly, a 826-bp fragment of Moca-cyp (encompassing nucleotides 1337–2163) was PCR-amplified using gene-specific primers 5′-CATGCCAGCACTTACGGTG-3′ and 5′-GGTGAATCGTCACGCTTCC-3′. Then the fragment was purified, Klenow-treated, and cloned into the EcoRV site of pBluescript plasmid. For in vivo inducible expression analysis, pBluescript532 was digested with Ase1 (in the cDNA), Klenow-treated, and cut with NotI (in the vector). Then, the purified cDNA fragment (nucleotides 40–3001 of Moca-cypcDNA) was ligated to NotI- and XhoI (Klenow-treated)-digested pMTV5-His vector (Invitrogen). The recombinant plasmid was called pMTV5-His/Moca-cyp. The recombinant pETcyp532 plasmid (nucleotides 98–691 ofMoca-cyp cDNA) was constructed for PPIase activity measurement. For this purpose, first the PPIase domain of Moca-cyp was PCR-amplified using gene-specific primers: 1) (EcoR1-BspH1)-5′-ATGACGGTAAACAAACGCGACGCGGG-3′ and 2) (BamH1-KpnI)-5′-GGAGCGCCTCTTGTGCTTCTTCTC-3′. The PCR fragment was digested with BspH1 andBamH1 and ligated to NcoI and BamH1 cloning sites of pET28a vector (Novagen). Then pETcyp532 plasmid was used to overexpress and purify the cyclophilin domain of Moca-cyp using the following protocol: An overnight culture of Escherichia coli transformed with pET532, was used to inoculate 6 liters of growth media. At an A 600 of ∼0.5, bacteria were induced with 1 mmisopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside and grown an additional 3 h at 37 °C. Then bacteria were collected, resuspended in a Tricine buffer (10 mm Tricine, pH 8.2), disrupted using a French press (SLM Aminco), and centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was passed through a TSK-fractogel SO 3−column (Merck). Bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradient of KCl (up to 2 m), and fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE. The cyclophilin domain-containing fractions were pooled, dialyzed against the buffer, and bound to a TSK-affi-blue matrix (Merck). The elution was realized with 2 m KCl. Then fractions containing the cyclophilin domain were pooled and concentrated, and a size exclusion chromatography step was appended (buffer: 10 mm HEPES, pH 7.8, 100 mm KCl, 2 mmMgCl2, 1 mm dithiothreitol). The homogeneous protein fractions were pooled and frozen at −80 °C. Any contamination with periplasmic E. coli cypB was avoided, because the first purification step was designed in a way that the chosen pH prevented the binding of cypB to the matrix. This was confirmed by Western blot analysis with an anti-cypB antibody. For the construction of pGEX2TKL156, a fragment of Moca-cypcDNA (nucleotides 1831–1985) was PCR-amplified and inserted intoEcoR1 and BamH1 sites of pGEX2TKL vector. The recombinant plasmid thus obtained was used for fusion protein production (26Kaelin W.G. Pallas D.C. DeCaprio J.A. Kaye F.J. Livingston D.M. Cell. 1991; 64: 521-532Google Scholar) and anti-Moca-cyp antibody affinity purification (27Maniatis T. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1982Google Scholar). Expression screening was performed essentially as described previously (28Kaelin W.G.J. Krek W. Sellers W.R. DeCaprio J.A. Ajchenbaum F. Fuchs C.S. Chittenden T., Li, Y. Farnham P.J. Blanar M.A. Livingston D.M. Flemington E.K. Cell. 1992; 70: 351-364Google Scholar), using a lambdaZapII cDNA expression library constructed with 0- to 9-hDrosophila embryo cDNA. The partial cDNA 814 isolated through the first screening was used as a DNA probe for the screening of a lambdaZapII cDNA library constructed with 0- to 24-hDrosophila embryo cDNA. Multiple recombinant clones were isolated, and the clone 532 contained the longest cDNA. Two independent 5′-RACE (rapid amplification of 5′-cloned ends) experiments were realized to clone the 5′-end of Moca-cypcDNA. For the first set of experiments, a cDNA library constructed with 0- to 4-h Drosophila embryo cDNA was used to perform nested PCR amplifications, usingMoca-cyp-specific primers 5′-CGACCTTTGCTTCAGCCTC-3′ and 5′-GTCGCGTTTGTTTACCGTCA-3′ and vector specific primers corresponding to the plasmidic vector pNB40 (29Brown N.H. Kafatos F.C. J. Mol. Biol. 1988; 203: 425-437Google Scholar). Independently, a SMART RACE cDNA amplification kit (Clontech), and aMoca-cyp-specific primer 5′-CCCCGGTTGGCCATCGACAGCAGGAAG-3′ were used to isolate the 5′-end of Moca-cyp from S2 poly(A+) mRNA. Sequencing was performed with a PerkinElmer Life Sciences ABI Prism 310 Genetic Analyzer apparatus. Subsequently, sequences were processed and analyzed using DNASTAR sequence analysis programs. Searches within the non-redundant (NR) data base were performed using BLAST2 and PSI-BLAST programs running at the National Center for Biological Information (NCBI) (30Altschul S.F. Madden T.L. Schäffer A.A. Zhang J. Zhang Z. Miller W. Lipman D.J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 3389-3402Google Scholar). Hidden Markov Model (HMM) searches were carried out using the HMMER package (31Eddy S.R. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1996; 6: 361-365Google Scholar). Hydrophobic Cluster Analysis (HCA) was also used to study protein architecture into domains and to detect distant but significant relationships between compared sequences. HCA combines sequence comparison with secondary structure predictions and is particularly efficient at low levels of sequence identity (typically below 20–25%). Guidelines to the use of HCA were described elsewhere (32Callebaut I. Labesse G. Durand P. Poupon A. Canard L. Chomilier J. Henrissat B. Mornon J.P. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 1997; 53: 621-645Google Scholar). Secondary structure predictions were performed using the profile neural network prediction PHD program (33Rost B. Sander C. J. Mol. Biol. 1993; 232: 584-599Google Scholar). Three-dimensional model was constructed using Modeler-3 (34Sali A. Blundell T.L. J. Mol. Biol. 1993; 234: 779-815Google Scholar), using the experimental structure of the uncomplexed form of Brugia malayi Cyp1 as template (PDB identifier: 1A58). Cytoplasmic RNAs were extracted fromDrosophila S2 cells as described previously (35Modjtahedi N. Lavialle C. Poupon M.-F. Landin R.-M. Cassingena R. Monier R. Brison O. Cancer Res. 1985; 45: 4372-4379Google Scholar). Poly(A+) RNAs were purified (mRNA purification kit, Amersham Biosciences), resolved by electrophoresis in a 1.2% agarose-formaldehyde gel and transferred to a ZetaProbe membrane (Bio-Rad) in 0.15 mNH 4+ acetate buffer. After transfer, the membrane was prehybridized for 1 h in Church buffer (36Church G.M. Gilbert W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1984; 81: 1991-1995Google Scholar) and then hybridized for 16 h at 65 °C in the same buffer supplemented with the 32P-labeled probe (Megaprime kit, AmershamBiosciences). Then the filter was washed twice with 0.5× SSC/0.1% SDS (1× SSC is 0.15 m NaCl, 0.015 m sodium citrate) for 15 min at 65 °C and exposed to an autoradiographic film. GST fusion proteins were expressed in bacteria and recovered on glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads (26Kaelin W.G. Pallas D.C. DeCaprio J.A. Kaye F.J. Livingston D.M. Cell. 1991; 64: 521-532Google Scholar) (Amersham Biosciences). pMet814 and pBluescript532 were in vitro transcribed and translated (TnT-coupled reticulocyte lysate, Promega) in the presence of [35S]methionine (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Radiolabeled translation products were incubated with the indicated GST fusion proteins in 400 μl of Net.N supplemented with protease inhibitors (1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 μg/ml each of aprotinin, leupeptin, and pepstatin) for 45 min at 4 °C. After five washes in the same buffer, precipitated proteins were boiled in 1× SB, resolved by SDS-PAGE, and visualized by autoradiography, after EN3HANCE (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) treatment of the gel. S2 cells were grown at 20 °C in Schneider media (Invitrogen) supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (Sigma) and transfected using an Invitrogen calcium phosphate transfection kit and protocols. 24 h after transfection, transient expression of pMTV5-His/Moca-cyp was induced by the addition of 0.5 mm CuSO4 to the growth medium for 24–48 h. Pools of stably transfected S2 cells expressing pMTV5-His or pMTV5-His/LacZ or pMTV5-His/Moca-cyp were also established in the presence of 300 μg/ml hygromycin (Invitrogen, following the supplier's protocols). Rabbit Moca-cyp antiserum SE2382 (Eurogentech) was developed against a synthetic peptide of Moca-cyp extending over amino acids 594–608 (QDNEYRNRYPLSPIR). The affinity purification and elution (27Maniatis T. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1982Google Scholar) of anti-Moca-cyp antibodies from SE2382 polyclonal serum was realized using the pGEX2TKL156 fusion protein. Anti-V5 is a purified mouse monoclonal antibody (Invitrogen). Untransfected and transfected cells were harvested, washed three times with ice-cold TBS buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl at pH 8.0, 120 mm NaCl), and lysed for 30 min at 4 °C in Net.N (20 mm Tris-HCl at pH 8.0, 120 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 0.5% Nonidet P-40) or EBC (50 mmTris-HCl at pH 8.0, 120 mm NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40) buffer supplemented with protease inhibitors (20 μg/μl each aprotinin, leupeptin, pepstatin, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and phosphatase inhibitors (1 mmNa3VO4 and 1 mm NaF). Then the lysate was centrifuged for 10 min at 13,000 × g to pellet cell debris. Proteins present in the supernatant were quantified (Bio-Rad) and then directly resolved by SDS-PAGE after boiling in 1× SB (2% SDS, 10% glycerol, 62.5 mm Tris-HCl at pH 6.8, 100 mm dithiothreitol) or subjected to immunoprecipitation and/or Western blot analysis. Nuclear extract was prepared according to Andrews and Faller (37Andrews N.C. Faller D.V. Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 249-256Google Scholar). Drosophila embryo extracts (gift of C. Antoniewski and D. Szymczak) were prepared as follows: Drosophila w1118 eggs collected at different times of embryogenesis were ground (volume to volume) in the cracking buffer (125 mm Tris-HCl at pH 6.8, 5% β-mercaptoethanol, 2% SDS, and 4 m urea) and analyzed by Western blot using affinity-purified SE2382 anti-Moca-cyp antibodies. The loading of the samples was controlled by Western blot analysis using the rabbit polyclonal anti-MBF1(a gift of M. Jindra) raised against the constitutively expressed Drosophilamultiprotein bridging factor 1 (MBF1) (M. Jindra, personal communication). Immunoprecipitations were carried out using the following procedure: Indicated antibodies were first pre-adsorbed to protein A-Sepharose CL-4B beads (40 μl of a 50% slurry, Amersham Biosciences) for 1 h at 4 °C in 500 μl of NET.N buffer. After three washes in the same buffer, antibody-loaded beads were incubated with 500 μg of cell lysate, for 1 h at 4 °C in a 600-μl incubation volume. Then, beads were washed five times with NET.N buffer, proteins were eluted by boiling in 1× SB, resolved by SDS-PAGE, and subjected to Western blot analysis. For Western blot analysis, proteins were transferred onto nitrocellulose membrane (Schleicher and Schuell) using Towbin buffer (38Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Google Scholar) and a liquid electrotransfer device. After transfer, membranes were blocked, in 5% nonfat dried milk in TBST buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl at pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, 0.05% Tween 20) supplemented with sodium azide (0.1%) for 2 h, and then incubated for 16 h at room temperature with the specified primary antibody diluted in the same buffer. After several washes with TBST, the blot was incubated with a horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody and developed using an ECL chemiluminescence detection kit (Amersham Biosciences). To measure the specificity of SE2382 polyclonal serum, 50 μg/lane of S2 cell extract were Western blot analyzed using a 1:2500 dilution of the polyclonal serum preincubated or not with 1 mg/ml free antigenic peptide. Stably transfected S2 cells expressing pMTV5-His or pMTV5-His/LacZ or pMTV5-His/Moca-cyp were seeded onto chamber slides (LAB-TEK) in the growth media and induced with 0.5 mm CuSO4. After 24 h of induction, cells were fixed with 2% paraformaldehyde and then incubated for 3 min with methanol at room temperature. V5-tagged proteins were detected by incubation with an anti-V5 mouse monoclonal antibody at 1 μg/ml (in phosphate-buffered saline/Tween 0.5%/bovine serum albumin 3%) followed by a goat anti-mouse antibody conjugated to fluorescein isothiocyanate (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories). Samples were DNA-stained with 0.5 μg/ml 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole, mounted using Vectashield mounting medium H-1000 (Vector Laboratories) and observed by confocal microscopy (Leica Microsystems SA, HCX PLAPO CS 63/1.32–0.60 oil). Whole-mount RNA in situhybridization experiments were performed according to Gavis and Lehmann (39Gavis E.R. Lehman R. Cell. 1992; 71: 301-313Google Scholar). Antisense and sense digoxigenin-labeled RNA probes were prepared using the pSKPCR2–532 plasmid (labeling kit, Roche Molecular Biochemicals, according to the supplier's protocol). Embryos were mounted in Spurr embedding medium (Sigma). In situhybridizations on polytene chromosomes were prepared as described previously (40Lemeunier F. Aulard S. Popscu P. Hayes H. Dutrillaux B. Techniques in Animal Cytogenetics. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2000: 137-149Google Scholar). All steps of embryo preparation and incubation with the antibody were carried out as described in Gavis and Lehmann (39Gavis E.R. Lehman R. Cell. 1992; 71: 301-313Google Scholar). The affinity-purified anti-Moca-cyp antibodies were used at a 1:200 dilution, and detection was realized with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody using the Vectastain Elite ABC Kit (Vector Laboratories). Embryos were mounted in Spurr embedding medium (Sigma) and analyzed. PPIase activity was measured according to Hani et al. (41Hani J. Schelbert B. Bernhardt A. Domdey H. Fischer G. Wiebauer K. Rahfeld J.U. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 108-116Google Scholar). Inhibition of PPIase activity was measured by preincubating CsA with the enzyme in the mixture for 5 min at 10 °C before starting the reaction by the addition of the substrate and the α-chymotrypsin. The inhibition constant K i was calculated according to a slow tight binding model with the following formula, f=kenz2×([E]−Ki−[I]+([E]−Ki−[I])2+4[E]Ki)Equation 1 where [E] is enzyme concentration, [I] is inhibitor concentration, and k enz is enzymatic acceleration of the followed reaction. With the aim of searching for nuclear proteins involved in the regulation of p300/CBP-dependent transcription, a protein fusion of glutathione S-transferase (GST) to the CH3 domain ofDrosophila CREB-binding protein (dCBP) (amino acids 2366–2540) (25Akimaru H. Chen Y. Dai P. Hou D.-X. Nonaka M. Smolik s.M. Armstrong S. Goodman R.H. Ishii S. Nature. 1997; 386: 735-738Google Scholar) was radiolabeled and used as a probe to screen aDrosophila embryo cDNA expression library. Thus, the clone 814 (1.2 kb) was isolated and analyzed. A fragment of the isolated cDNA was subcloned (p814ES) and used as a probe for Northern blot analysis of poly(A)+ mRNA prepared from S2 cells (Fig. 1 B). Two poly(A)+ mRNAs of about 3.5 and 4.3 kb were detected. Because the cloned cDNA 814 had a poly(A)+ tail and was shorter than the two mRNA detected by Northern blot analysis, we concluded that it was not complete and the corresponding 5′-end was missing. Another round of cDNA library screening was realized using a p814ES radiolabeled DNA probe. Among multiple cDNA clones isolated, the longest one (clone 532) was fully sequenced and further analyzed (Fig. 1 A). The clone 532 contained a poly(A)+ tail and its 5′ end corresponded to the position 40 of the nucleotide sequence presented in figure 1A. The 5′ end of the cDNA (Fig. 1 A) was obtained by PCR amplification (see “Experimental Procedures”). The full-length composite cDNA (named Moca-cyp), which spans 3177 nucleotides, co

Interaction of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) envelope glycoproteins with the CCR5 chemokine receptor, a G-protein-coupled receptor, triggers a membrane fusion process and virus entry. Cooperation for HIV-1 receptor activity was observed when two forms of CCR5 were coexpressed, either the wild-type (WT) receptor and a defective mutant with deletion of the amino-terminal (NT) extracellular domain or the latter ΔNT mutant and a human-mouse CCR5 chimera bearing the NT domain from human CCR5. Cooperation was most efficient when the two forms of CCR5 were in a 1:1 ratio. It was not observed between the CCR5 ΔNT mutant and a chimeric receptor (5444) in which the NT domain of CCR5 was in the context of another G-protein-coupled receptor, the HIV-1 receptor CXCR4. These results suggested that physical association between two forms of CCR5 was required for their cooperation. Coimmunoprecipitation experiments in transfected cell lysates indeed showed that the ΔNT CCR5 mutant formed oligomeric complexes with the WT CCR5 or the HMMM chimera but not with the CXCR4-derived chimera 5444. These observations suggest that the formation of CCR5 oligomers is a constitutive process independent from activation by chemokine ligands. The interaction of HIV-1 with independent subunits of CCR5 oligomers could favor the local recruitment of fusiogenic proteins and the formation of a fusion pore. Cooperation for HIV-1 receptor activity was observed when two forms of CCR5 were coexpressed, either the wild-type (WT) receptor and a defective mutant with deletion of the amino-terminal (NT) extracellular domain or the latter ΔNT mutant and a human-mouse CCR5 chimera bearing the NT domain from human CCR5. It was not observed between the CCR5 ΔNT mutant and a chimeric receptor (5444) in which the NT domain of CCR5 was in the context of another G-protein-coupled receptor, the HIV-1 receptor CXCR4. These results suggested that physical association between two forms of CCR5 was required for their cooperation. Coimmunoprecipitation experiments in transfected cell lysates indeed showed that the ΔNT CCR5 mutant formed oligomeric complexes with the WT CCR5 or the HMMM chimera but not with the CXCR4-derived chimera 5444. These observations suggest that the formation of CCR5 oligomers is a constitutive process independent from activation by chemokine ligands. G-protein-coupled receptor macrophage inflammatory protein human immunodeficiency virus type 1 glycoprotein amino-terminal membrane-spanning domains monoclonal antibody wild-type regulated on activation normal T cell expressed and secreted human embryonic kidney green fluorescent protein 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-β-d-galactopyranoside phycoerythrin envelope glycoprotein Chemokines represent a family of at least 40 structurally related small proteins (8–10 kDa) mediating chemotactic migration of leukocytes through binding and activating receptors with seven membrane-spanning domains coupled to heterotrimeric G proteins (GPCR)1 (for review see Refs.1Loetscher P. Moser B. Baggiolini M. Adv. Immunol. 2000; 74: 127-179Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Mackay C.R. Nat. Immunol. 2001; 2: 95-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (718) Google Scholar, 3Murphy P.M. Baggiolini M. Charo I.F. Hebert C.A. Horuk R. Matsushima K. Miller L.H. Oppenheim J.J. Power C.A. Pharmacol. Rev. 2000; 52: 145-176PubMed Google Scholar, 4Rossi D. Zlotnick A. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 217-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (2109) Google Scholar). Chemokines are classified according to the relative position of two conserved cysteine residues in their amino-terminal region, the major subgroups being termed CXC (or α) and CC (or β) and the same nomenclature (CXCR and CCR) used to designate their receptors (5Zlotnik A. Yoshie O. Immunity. 2000; 12: 121-127Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3306) Google Scholar). In addition to their role in cell signal transduction, chemokine receptors have attracted a lot of interest because they represent cell entry portals for the human immunodeficiency viruses (HIV-1 and HIV-2) and related simian or feline retroviruses. A list of chemokine receptors or related orphan GPCRs can mediate HIV-1 entry in certain experimental conditions, but only two of them, CCR5 and CXCR4, seem to be usedin vivo. The predominant role of CCR5 is indicated by the resistance to HIV-1 infection of individuals genetically deficient for the expression of this receptor, the most frequent defect being a 32-nucleotide deletion (Δ32 allele) resulting in a translation frameshift after residue 187 (reviewed in Refs. 6Berger E.A. Murphy P.M. Farber J.M. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1999; 17: 657-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (1890) Google Scholar, 7Brelot A. Alizon M. AIDS. 2001; 15: S3-S11Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 8Doms R.W. AIDS. 2001; 15 (Suppl. 1): S34-S35Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 9Simmons G. Reeves J.D. Hibbitts S. Stine J.T. Gray P.W. Proudfoot A.E. Clapham P.R. Immunol. Rev. 2000; 177: 112-126Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Although HIV-1 strains infecting cells via CCR5 (termed R5 strains) can be isolated throughout infection, strains using CXCR4 (termed X4) or both receptors (R5X4) generally emerge at more advanced stages. The selectivity of HIV-1 for CCR5 or CXCR4 can explain differences in cell tropism such as the ability of R5 but not X4 strains to replicate in macrophages. The inhibition of HIV-1 infection by chemokines and other CCR5 or CXCR4 ligands raises hope for novel antiviral strategies (1Loetscher P. Moser B. Baggiolini M. Adv. Immunol. 2000; 74: 127-179Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Brelot A. Alizon M. AIDS. 2001; 15: S3-S11Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 10Moore J.P. Stevenson M. Nature Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2001; 1: 40-49Crossref Scopus (172) Google Scholar) and stimulates investigations on the role of these receptors in the initial steps of the virus life cycle. The cell entry of HIV-1 and other retroviruses is mediated by their envelope glycoproteins (Env), which consist in trimeric complexes of a surface subunit (gp120 in the case of HIV-1) responsible for contacts with target cells and a transmembrane subunit (gp41) mediating membrane fusion (reviewed in Refs. 11Wyatt R. Sodroski J. Science. 1998; 280: 1884-1888Crossref PubMed Scopus (1318) Google Scholar, 12Poignard P. Saphire E.O. Parren P.W. Burton D.R. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2001; 19: 253-274Crossref PubMed Scopus (228) Google Scholar, 13Weissenhorn W. Dessen A. Calder L.J. Harrisson S.C. Skehel J.J. Wiley D.C. Mol. Membr. Biol. 1999; 16: 3-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (324) Google Scholar). The conformation changes in the Env complex required to activate the fusiogenic properties of gp41 are considered to be triggered by the interaction of gp120 with CCR5 or CXCR4. This interaction has been observed by different techniques, usually in presence of soluble forms of the CD4 protein that led to consider CCR5 and CXCR4 as CD4-associated HIV-1 coreceptors (14Lapham C.K. Ouyang J. Chandrasekhar B. Nguyen N.Y. Dimitrov D.S. Golding H. Science. 1996; 274: 602-605Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar, 15Trkola A. Dragic T. Arthos J. Binley J.M. Olson W.C. Allaway G. Martin S.R. Cheng-Mayer C. Robinson J. Maddon P.J. Moore J.P. Nature. 1996; 384: 184-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (959) Google Scholar, 16Wu L. Gerard N.P. Wyatt R. Choe H. Parolin C. Ruffing N. Borsetti A. Cardoso A.A. Desjardin E. Newman W. Gerard C. Sodroski J. Nature. 1996; 384: 179-183Crossref PubMed Scopus (1083) Google Scholar). However, the possibility of CD4-independent binding of gp120 to CCR5 and CXCR4 (17Bandres J.C. Wang Q.F. O'Leary J. Baleux F. Amara A. Hoxie J.A. Zolla-Pazner S. Gorny M.K. J. Virol. 1998; 72: 2500-2504Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 18Hesselgesser J. Halks-Miller M. DelVecchio V. Peiper S. Hoxie J. Kolson D.L. Taub D. Horuk R. Curr. Biol. 1997; 7: 112-121Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 19Hoffman T.L. LaBranche C.C. Zhang W. Canziani G. Robinson J. Chaiken I. Hoxie J.A. Doms R.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 6359-6364Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar) as well as evolutionary and mechanistic considerations also allows us to view them as stricto sensu HIV-1 receptors. How CCR5 or CXCR4 interact with gp120 is not known at the molecular level. The current view is that the functional interaction with HIV-1 gp120, i.e.leading to infection, is mediated by the extracellular domains of chemokine receptors, in particular their amino-terminal (NT) domain and second extracellular loop, whereas their intracellular domains coupled to the cell signaling machinery are dispensable, at least in experimental situations (reviewed in Refs. 6Berger E.A. Murphy P.M. Farber J.M. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 1999; 17: 657-700Crossref PubMed Scopus (1890) Google Scholar, 20Berson J.F. Doms R.W. Semin. Immunol. 1998; 10: 237-248Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar, and 21Hoffman T.L. Doms R.W. AIDS. 1998; 12 (Suppl. A): S17-S26PubMed Google Scholar). The ability of CCR5 and CXCR4 to interact with gp120 is certainly a critical parameter, but it can be wondered if other features could also contribute to their HIV-1 receptor activity. Discrepancies have indeed been reported between gp120 binding and efficiency of HIV-1 infection in certain experiments (22Baik S.S. Doms R.W. Doranz B.J. Virology. 1999; 259: 267-273Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 23Doranz B.J. Orsini M.J. Turner J.D. Hoffman T.L. Berson J.F. Hoxie J.A. Peiper S.C. Brass L.F. Doms R.W. J. Virol. 1999; 73: 2752-2761Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Among parameters proposed to influence the HIV-1 receptor activity of CCR5 or CXCR4 are their association with CD4 (14Lapham C.K. Ouyang J. Chandrasekhar B. Nguyen N.Y. Dimitrov D.S. Golding H. Science. 1996; 274: 602-605Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar, 24Ugolini S. Moulard M. Mondor I. Barois N. Demandolx D. Hoxie J. Brelot A. Alizon M. Davoust J. Sattentau Q. J. Immunol. 1997; 159: 3000-3008PubMed Google Scholar, 25Xiao X., Wu, L. Stantchev T.S. Feng Y.R. Ugolini S. Chen H. Shen Z. Riley J.L. Broder C.C. Sattentau Q.J. Dimitrov D.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 7496-7501Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar) and their density at the cell surface (26Platt E.J. Wehrly K. Kuhmann S.E. Chesebro B. Kabat D. J. Virol. 1998; 72: 2855-2864Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27Kuhmann S.E. Platt E.J. Kozak S.L. Kabat D. J. Virol. 2000; 74: 7005-7015Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar), which both could be linked to localization in particular domains of the plasma membrane such as glycolipid-rich “rafts” (28Liao Z. Cimakasky L.M. Hampton R. Nguyen D.H. Hildreth J.E. AIDS Res. Hum. Retroviruses. 2001; 17: 1009-1019Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar). A high local density of HIV-1 receptors could favor the clustering of activated viral fusiogenic proteins that seems important for the formation of fusion pores (29Bentz J. Biophys. J. 2000; 78: 227-245Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 30Chernomordik L. Frolov V.A. Leikina E. Bronk P. Zimmerberg J. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 1369-1382Crossref PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar, 31Monck J.R. Fernandez J.M. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1996; 8: 524-533Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). In line with this view, the oligomeric status of chemokine receptors could represent an important parameter for HIV-1 infection. The possibility that GPCRs form oligomeric complexes has been the matter of a long debate but now seems to be an accepted fact supported by a list of coimmunoprecipitation and transcomplementation experiments and more recently evidenced by biophysical techniques based on light resonance energy transfer (for reviews see Refs. 32Angers S. Salahpour A. Bouvier M. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2002; 42: 409-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (517) Google Scholar, 33Bouvier M. Nat. Rev. 2001; 2: 274-286Crossref Scopus (584) Google Scholar, 34Milligan G. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 1265-1271Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). There is still no consensus on the possible function(s) of such dimers or higher order oligomers of GPCRs. In most instances, the formation of such structures appears to be a constitutive process, independent from the activation of these receptors by their ligands (32Angers S. Salahpour A. Bouvier M. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2002; 42: 409-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (517) Google Scholar). Conflicting results have been obtained in the case of chemokine receptors. In a series of studies, the formation of CCR5, CCR2, or CXCR4 homodimers as well as CCR5/CCR2 heterodimers was found to occur upon treatment of cells with the cognate chemokine ligands (35Vicente-Manzanares M. Montoya M.C. Mellado M. Frade J.M. del Pozo M.A. Nieto M. de Landazuri M.O. Martinez A.C. Sanchez-Madrid F. Eur. J. Immunol. 1998; 28: 2197-2207Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar, 36Vila-Coro A.J. Mellado M. Martin de Ana A. Lucas P. del Real G. Martinez A.C. Rodriguez-Frade J.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 3388-3393Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 37Rodriguez-Frade J.M. Vila-Coro A.J. de Ana A.M. Albar J.P. Martinez A.C. Mellado M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 3628-3633Crossref PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar, 38Mellado M. Rodriguez-Frade J.M. Vila-Coro A.J. Fernandez S. Martin de Ana A. Jones D.R. Toran J.L. Martinez A.C. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 2497-2507Crossref PubMed Scopus (384) Google Scholar). On the contrary, Benkirane et al. found that wild-type CCR5 could be trapped in the endoplasmic reticulum of cells expressing the truncated form of CCR5 (residues 1–187) encoded by the Δ32 allele and proposed that formation of dimers was a constitutive process necessary for efficient processing of the receptor to the cell surface (39Benkirane M. Jin D.Y. Chun R.F. Koup R.A. Jeang K.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30603-30606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar). Although such an effect of the Δ32 mutant on the cell surface expression of CCR5 could not be evidenced in a recent study (40Venkatesan S. Petrovic A. Van Ryk D.I. Locati M. Weissman D. Murphy P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 2287-2301Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), we have reported experiments confirming the finding of Benkirane et al. (39Benkirane M. Jin D.Y. Chun R.F. Koup R.A. Jeang K.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30603-30606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar) and suggesting that the transdominant negative effect involved interactions between membrane-spanning domains of the two proteins, in particular TM3 of CCR5 and TM4 of Δ32 (41Chelli M. Alizon M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 46975-46982Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). In similar experiments, we found that the HIV-1 receptor activity of CCR5 was enhanced when cells coexpressed a functionally defective CCR5 mutant obtained by complete deletion of the amino-terminal extracellular domain. Another example of cooperation between two forms of CCR5 was obtained by rescuing HIV-1 receptor activity upon expressing two defective CCR5 mutants in transfected cells. This functional transcomplementation apparently required physical association of the different forms of CCR5 detected in coimmunoprecipitation experiments. These results provide strong and direct evidence for the formation of constitutive CCR5 oligomers and shed new light on the molecular interplay between the HIV-1 envelope proteins and the target cell membrane. Seman M. Alizon M. Science. 1997; 276: 1874-1878Crossref PubMed Scopus (286) Google Scholar). Cells were transfected in 6-well trays (5 × 105 cells/well) with a total amount of 3 μg of DNA/well. Co-cultures or infections were initiated 24 h later by adding an equivalent number of freshly trypsinized HeLa-Env/ADA cells or 105 infectious units of each R5 HIV-1 strains. After 24 h (or 36 h for infections), the cells were washed, fixed in 0.5% glutaraldehyde, and stained for β-galactosidase activity with X-gal. Blue-stained foci were scored under ×20 magnification. Cell counts >200 were obtained by extrapolation from randomly selected fields. The surface expression of chemokine receptor was monitored as described previously (52Brelot A. Heveker N. Pleskoff O. Sol N. Alizon M. J. Virol. 1997; 71: 4744-4751Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). HEK293T cells were detached with phosphate-buffered saline, 1 mm EDTA 36 h after cotransfection with GPCR and GFP expression vectors (6:1 ratio). Cells were incubated 1 h at 4 °C in phosphate-buffered saline, 2% fetal calf serum with 1 μg/ml of anti-CCR5 (2D7 or 3A9) or anti-CXCR4 (12G5) mAb and then washed and stained for 1 h at 4 °C with phycoerythrin (PE)-conjugated secondary antibody before fixation in 4% paraformaldehyde. The green (GFP) and red (CCR5 or CXCR4) fluorescence was analyzed on an Epics Elite flow cytometer (Coultronics). Results are shown as the percentage of PE-positive cells or mean PE intensity in the GFP-positive fraction as indicated. Approximately 107 transfected HEK293T cells or CEM cells were lysed by incubation for 1 h at 4 °C in 1 ml of 0.5%n-dodecyl-d-maltoside (Sigma), 25 mmTris-HCl (pH 7.4), 140 mm NaCl, 2 mm EDTA, 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (Sigma), protease and phosphatase inhibitors. Cell lysates were clarified by centrifugation (12,000 × g for 15 min), and immunoprecipitations were performed at 4 °C on 1-ml samples (1 mg of proteins) by contact with 1 μg of 2D7 or anti-c-Myc mAb (2 h) and protein G-agarose (Roche Molecular Biochemicals). Proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nylon membranes before contact with the 3A9, M2 (anti-FLAG), or 9E10 (anti-c-Myc) mAb (all at 1 μg/ml) and then with peroxidase-coupled anti-mouse IgGs (0.5 μg/ml). The reaction was revealed with ECL reagents (Amersham Biosciences). The HIV-1 receptor activity of CCR5 was assayed by transient transfection of CD4+ HeLa-P4 cells followed by infection by R5 HIV-1 strains (ADA, JRCSF, or YU2) or co-culture with HeLa-Env/ADA cells (44Pleskoff O. Treboute C. Brelot A. Heveker N. Seman M. Alizon M. Science. 1997; 276: 1874-1878Crossref PubMed Scopus (286) Google Scholar). Infection by HIV-1 or fusion with Env+ cells (also expressing the HIV-1-transactivating protein, Tat) activates a β-galactosidase (lacZ) transgene in HeLa-P4 cells, allowing us to quantify these events by staining with X-gal. Syncytia formation and HIV-1 infection were not detected when HeLa-P4 cells expressed the ΔNT CCR5 mutant corresponding to a 25-residue deletion in the amino-terminal extracellular domain (Fig.1, A and B). Unexpectedly, the cotransfection of this defective mutant and the wild-type (WT) CCR5 resulted in markedly higher numbers of syncytia with Env+ cells and HIV-1 infection events by comparison with cells transfected with the WT CCR5 only (Fig. 1, A andB). The efficiency of cell fusion or infection was similar for cells transfected with equal amounts (1.5 μg) of WT and ΔNT CCR5 vectors or with 3 μg of the WT CCR5 vector. The cooperation observed in this experiment could either be because of functional complementation of the defective mutant or enhanced expression of the WT receptor. The cell surface expression of the two forms of CCR5 was assayed by flow cytometry after staining with the 3A9 or 2D7 mAbs, which react with the NT domain and the second extracellular loop of CCR5, respectively. Similar flow cytometry profiles were obtained for cells transfected with the WT CCR5 or the ΔNT mutant upon staining with the 2D7 mAb, indicating that the deletion did not affect cell surface expression, whereas the 3A9 mAb only stained cells expressing WT CCR5 as expected (Fig. 2 A; TableI). An analysis of HeLa-P4 cells cotransfected with equal amounts of the WT CCR5 vector and either a control plasmid or the ΔNT CCR5 vector revealed similar staining efficiency with the 3A9 mAb (Fig. 2 B). Therefore, the enhanced HIV-1 receptor activity of cells coexpressing WT and ΔNT CCR5 seemed to be attributed to a complementation effect.Table IRelative cell surface expression of CCR5, CXCR4, and derivatives in transfected HEK293T cellsReactivity with mAb2D73A912G5%CCR51001000ΔNT11200HMMM3.2890CXCR400100544405289Flow cytometry analysis was performed as shown in Fig. 2. To obtain further evidence of cooperation between two forms of CCR5, we sought to rescue HIV-1 receptor function by coexpressing the ΔNT mutant and another defective forms of CCR5. In our hands, point mutations in the extracellular loops of CCR5 had a very limited functional effect, whereas the deletions were not compatible with transport of CCR5 to the cell surface, probably because they caused improper folding and intracellular retention of the polypeptide chain. Therefore, our option was to use a CCR5 chimera (HMMM) in which the NT and TM1 domains derived from human CCR5 (H) and other domains from its mouse homologue (M). Although such a chimeric receptor has been reported to be a functional HIV-1 receptor (51Picard L. Simmons G. Power C.A. Meyer A. Weiss R.A. Clapham P.R. J. Virol. 1997; 71: 5003-5011Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 53Bieniasz P.D. Fridell R.A. Aramori I. Ferguson S.S. Caron M.G. Cullen B.R. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 2599-2609Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar), its activity was very low in our assays. It was <10% relatively to WT CCR5 in fusion assays between transfected HeLa-P4 cells and HeLa-Env/ADA cells (Fig. 3 A) and in infections with the YU-2 and JRCSF HIV-1 strains (Fig.3 B), whereas infection by HIV-1 ADA was somehow more efficient (∼30% relatively to WT CCR5). Flow cytometry analysis with the 3A9 mAb indicates that the lower HIV-1 receptor activity of the HMMM chimera does not result from reduced surface expression (Table Iand Fig. 2 A). Cotransfection of CCR5 ΔNT and HMMM expression vectors (1.5 μg each) in HeLa-P4 cells resulted in efficient fusion with HeLa-Env/ADA cells and infection by the HIV-1 JRCSF and YU-2 strains, whereas infection by HIV-1 ADA strain was markedly increased (Fig. 3,A and B). The number of syncytia or infection events was comparable with those seen when HeLa-P4 cells were transfected with 1.5 μg of WT CCR5, again indicating that the functional complementation of these two CCR5 mutants is a relatively efficient process. Flow cytometry analysis confirmed that the ΔNT mutant did not up-regulate the surface expression of the HMMM receptor (Fig. 2 B). In similar experiments, the CCR5 ΔNT mutant was not rescued by coexpressing the mouse CCR5 or other chimeric receptors not containing the amino-terminal domain of human CCR5 2M. Chelli and M. Chem. 2001; 276: 46975-46982Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). To find out whether complementation was possible when the NT domain of CCR5 was in the context of a more distant GPCR, it was substituted to the homologous domain of CXCR4. Flow cytometry analysis showed that the resulting 5444 chimera and WT CXCR4 were expressed at a similar level in transfected cells, whereas the reactivity with the 3A9 mAb was ∼50% relative to WT CCR5 (Table I), indicating that the amino-terminal domain of CCR5 was accessible. Upon expression of the 5444 chimera in HeLa-P4 cells we could detect fusion with HeLa-Env/ADA cells at a relatively low level (∼20% relative to WT CCR5) (Fig. 3 A), which is in agreement with observations made with similar chimeric receptors (54Pontow S. Ratner L. J. Virol. 2001; 75: 11503-11514Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The efficiency of fusion was not enhanced when HeLa-P4 cells coexpressed the 5444 chimeric receptor and the ΔNT mutant (Fig. 3 A). These different results suggested that the cooperation of different forms of CCR5 for HIV-1 receptor activity required some form of interplay that cannot take place with a more distant GPCR such as CXCR4. It obviously led to an envision that functional complementation involved the formation of dimers or higher order oligomers. In cells expressing two receptors capable to efficiently associate, the relative proportions of homodimers and heterodimers can be deduced from simple equations and follow theoretical curves shown in Fig.4 A. Polyglutamine disease is now recognized as one of the conformational, amyloid-related diseases. In this disease, polyglutamine expansion in proteins has toxic effects on cells and also results in the formation of aggregates. Polyglutamine aggregate formation is accompanied by conversion of the polyglutamine from a soluble to an insoluble form. In yeast, the efficiency of the aggregate formation is determined by the balance of various parameters, including the length of the polyglutamine tract, the function of Hsp104, and the level of polyglutamine expression. In this study, we found that the co-expression of a long polyglutamine tract, which formed aggregates independently of the function of Hsp104, enhanced the formation of aggregates of a short polyglutamine tract in wild-type cells as well as in Δhsp104 mutant cells. Thus, the expression of a long polyglutamine tract would be an additional parameter determining the efficiency of aggregate formation of a short polyglutamine tract. The co-localization of aggregates of long and short polyglutamine tracts suggests the possibility that the enhancement occurs due to the seeding of aggregates of the long polyglutamine tracts.
